user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_increment_response_rc:
```c
void
MHD_increment_response_rc (struct MHD_Response *response)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
  (response->reference_count)++;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&response->mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_increment_response_rc:
#define MHD_mutex_lock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_lock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to lock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
...
#define MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_(pmutex) do{if(!MHD_mutex_unlock_(pmutex))MHD_PANIC(_("Failed to unlock mutex.\n"));\
}while(0)
...
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
...
struct MHD_Response
{

  /**
   * Head of double-linked list of headers to send for the response.
   */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *first_header;

  /**
   * Tail of double-linked list of headers to send for the response.
   */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *last_header;

  /**
   * Buffer pointing to data that we are supposed
   * to send as a response.
   */
  const char *data;

  /**
   * Closure to give to the content reader @e crc
   * and content reader free callback @e crfc.
   */
  void *crc_cls;

  /**
   * How do we get more data?  NULL if we are
   * given all of the data up front.
   */
  MHD_ContentReaderCallback crc;

  /**
   * NULL if data must not be freed, otherwise
   * either user-specified callback or "&free".
   */
  MHD_ContentReaderFreeCallback crfc;

#ifdef UPGRADE_SUPPORT
  /**
   * Application function to call once we are done sending the headers
   * of the response; NULL unless this is a response created with
   * #MHD_create_response_for_upgrade().
   */
  MHD_UpgradeHandler upgrade_handler;

  /**
   * Closure for @e uh.
   */
  void *upgrade_handler_cls;
#endif /* UPGRADE_SUPPORT */

#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  /**
   * Mutex to synchronize access to @e data, @e size and
   * @e reference_count.
   */
  MHD_mutex_ mutex;
#endif

  /**
   * The size of the response body.
   * Set to #MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN if size is not known.
   */
  uint64_t total_size;

  /**
   * At what offset in the stream is the
   * beginning of @e data located?
   */
  uint64_t data_start;

  /**
   * Offset to start reading from when using @e fd.
   */
  uint64_t fd_off;

  /**
   * Number of bytes ready in @e data (buffer may be larger
   * than what is filled with payload).
   */
  size_t data_size;

  /**
   * Size of the writable data buffer @e data.
   */
  size_t data_buffer_size;

  /**
   * Reference count for this response.  Free once the counter hits
   * zero.
   */
  unsigned int reference_count;

  /**
   * File-descriptor if this response is FD-backed.
   */
  int fd;

  /**
   * Flags set for the MHD response.
   */
  enum MHD_ResponseFlags flags;

  /**
   * Automatic flags set for the MHD response.
   */
  enum MHD_ResponseAutoFlags flags_auto;

  /**
   * If the @e fd is a pipe (no sendfile()).
   */
  bool is_pipe;

  /**
   * I/O vector used with MHD_create_response_from_iovec.
   */
  MHD_iovec_ *data_iov;

  /**
   * Number of elements in data_iov.
   */
  unsigned int data_iovcnt;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No unreachable code was identified in the provided function. Rationale:

- The function contains only two conditional-compilation blocks (mutex lock/unlock) and an increment of response->reference_count. The provided additional code defines MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, so the lock/unlock code is compiled in and reachable at runtime.
- There are no early returns, infinite loops, or unconditional non-returning calls (e.g., calls to functions that are guaranteed not to return) that would make subsequent statements unreachable. The MHD_PANIC() call inside the MHD_mutex_*_chk_ macros is invoked only on the failure branch of an if and so does not render the following statements statically unreachable.
- No dead-code preprocessor branches (for example #if 0) are present in the supplied fragments.

Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied snippets that need investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
